content: this is dmg and we're going to be talking about stairways that go
right so how to craft ascending stairways
so I've pre-prepared a 3 by 1 square lot from video 2 as you've seen and a 2 by 1
and a single square as well 6 and 1/2 centimeter squares and that's how we're
going to stack them three layers so I measure seven millimeters on each side
all the way around and this is to show where the doors are going to be so I do
that on the middle point on the two square one so I'm only going to the
middle point because the third layer is going to be on the other side so then I
measure 1/2 which is three and a quarter centimeters and I measure that and then
cut along those lines from the edge to that three and a quarter centimeters and
then we rip out that layer to get down to the first layer of corrugated
cardboard I just make sure I'm cutting through that corrugation and we rip that
out just to get down to that middle layer clean it out with a craft knife
I'm going to stack that on top of the three by one and squares and again the
single square we're now just going to measure where the walls are going to be
seven millimeters rule them out and then measure three and a quarter centimeters
to the middle on both sides and rule a straight line and connect them up with
and then cut it out with the craft knife again down to the first layer of
corrugation and we're going to rip that out as we did with the previous piece so
you can then use the craft knife to clean up all the edges just so there are
things nice and clean and easy to work with so that's what it's going to be
three layers and then good and easy when you've got the all the lines ruled out
and that's why I do those large grids as you see in the second video so we can
see exactly where it's going to be the lines are already there and I just put
the hot glue all over the cardboard in order to connect everything up so now
we're going to attach the top layer same things hot glue just squiggle it all
over there so it gets a good grip and grab the single piece and stick it on
the top make sure everything is flush and now we're going to touch the wall so
curved wall piece again from video 2 will show you how to make those and make
sure that that's flush and just lob off the excess with the scissors and we do
that on the other side as well this is now on the lower step and the reason why
we using 3 and not 2 as we did in the downstairs is because I liked the walls
to jut over onto that piece so that's why now you'll see me measuring with the
wall how far over just a thickness of the wall just make the marks there and
then I measure the actual wall in place so I know where to cut it then we cut it
and I'm just going to measure the other piece as well so we've got to the right
size and we'll be able to glue them on at the same time so just here with the
hot glue put it on on both sides you'll see there is a little bit of wisps that
happen there you can just clean those off when you're finished and just stick
the door or the walls on and make sure everything is flush so you can see it
juts over onto that lower level and there we have it so now I've used all
the techniques from video 3 4 and 5 to get to this point and I'm creating a
very watery white on the first step and then add a little bit more white a bit
more water and go on to the second third and top layer now I never go above the
third layer in any of my tiles it's a sort of a personal thing that I've done
just to keep in with the 2.5 D method invented by DM Scotty and here you can
see I'm just dabbing off the water down paint with the with the sponge and then
with the boots of speeds I've sped it out of it I'm just going over lightly
over the advanced painting technique just to pick out those outlines of the
stone technique and to create the edging for the top layer of wall whether it
isn't actually a wall we're just faking it with a black line
and just do a little little bit of effect there on the top just against
it's a lot brighter and just the walls that hide the seams and
just smudge it with my finger just to increase the effect so now I'm going to
show you what it looks like when you're putting a dungeon together so as I was
saying you you if you don't go over the third layer of cardboard and you stick
to that level which is a you know what what I normally do it makes much easier
to store the tiles because you're not going up to five six layers of tiles and
becomes much easier to store everything and also easy for playability so you're
not having to you know work around very tall objects and things like that so
that's why I set a maximum for myself of three layers of cardboard as you can see
here it is very effective just quickly changing the orientation of
the dungeon and it's quite easy to you know change into a variety of different
corridors and passages and things I'm just going to put a door in here just to
show you what it looks like and that door was in video 7 just open it up see
what it looks like so that's how we do stairways going up and that's how I use
up to three levels of cardboard once again I don't go above three levels
mainly because I've just set myself that thing just to keep in spirit with a 2.5
D system that was invented by DM Scotty and I usually check out his channel the
DM is craft where you can find other interesting ideas of things like this
now if you like the video there's a button at the bottom that says like
otherwise you can subscribe to the videos and get new ones as they come out
and you can check out our website the DM G info and our Facebook page where we
